column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The process of developing IGO's first Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) was announced and initiated during Reconciliation Week in July 2022. Development of the Innovate IGO RAP was undertaken by the IGO Reconciliation Action Plan Working Group (RAPWG), which comprises IGO employees, in consultation with Traditional Owner representatives from across several of IGO's significant operations and exploration locations. Traditional Owner groups who participated included the Ngadju people (Nova Operation), Whadjuk Noongar people (South Perth Head office) and Martu people (Paterson Exploration).\t
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP), Traditional Owners, Consultation

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Making a Difference is at the core of everything we do, and IGO's Corporate Giving Program is another way we can live our purpose. We play an active role in our host communities and work collaboratively to build meaningful, transparent and trusting relationships. The relationships are vital for the Company's sustainable and expanding business, which results in more excellent value for our stakeholders.\t
column20: Corporate Giving Program, Community engagement, Sustainable business

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Our people demonstrated tremendous support for health and wellbeing initiatives and disaster relief throughout the year by actively contributing to employee-led fundraising initiatives for Movember, The Push-Up Challenge, and the Kimberley, NSW and Queensland Flood Appeals. Donations were matched by IGO, raising over $9,000 for these initiatives.\t
column20: Employee-led fundraising, Disaster relief, Corporate social responsibility

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Corporate giving encompasses more than making donations, and throughout the year, many employees went beyond their usual work environment and took the opportunity to use their volunteer leave to contribute to local charities in our community. Collectively, our employees volunteered 370 hours of their time through corporate volunteering initiatives.\t
column20: Volunteer leave, Corporate volunteering, Local charities

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: IGO has partnered with the Ngadju people at the Nova Operation since 2014, delivering an integrated program of social, cultural, environmental and economic benefits based on close and regular consultation with the Ngadju people and their representative, the NNTAC. In FY23, IGO's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander employment rate at the Nova Operation was five per cent, with more than three-quarters of these employees being people of Ngadju heritage. Employment and professional development of the Ngadju people are two focus areas at Nova.\t
column20: Indigenous rights, employment, training\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: CoRE Learning Foundation and IGO Hands-On Learning Program
column13: During the year, our employees and CoRE visited Norseman District High School to help facilitate the CoRE Learning Foundation and IGO Hands-On Learning Program, which provide mentoring opportunities for our Graduates while encouraging STEAM learning and participation for primary and secondary students. The CoRE Learning Foundation, founded by Suzy Urbaniak, is a not-for-profit organisation that works towards improving STEAM enrolments with a focus on non-traditional teaching methods, which move away from textbooks and focus on engaging with students using more practical techniques.\t
column20: CoRE Learning Foundation, Hands-On Learning Program, STEAM education

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Earbus Foundation is a Western Australian-based charity that works to reduce the incidence of middle ear disease in Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander and at-risk children in Western Australia through mobile ear health clinics. These clinics offer a model of continuous care in schools and daycares, providing comprehensive ear screening, surveillance and treatment, employing General Practitioners (GPs), Audiologists and Ear, Nose and Throat surgeons (ENTs) so that every child can achieve their full potential through listening and learning.\t
column20: Earbus Foundation, Ear health, Indigenous children

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Esperance District Football Association (EDFA) was formed in 1956 and is a not-for-profit association that endeavours to better children's health and wellbeing through playing football. Playing sports and being involved in the community positively impacts mental health. EDFA encourages children to be active and play sports to create a supportive and safe environment where they feel part of a team and a community. EDFA is proud to be associated with four clubs and eight playing divisions and has hundreds of hardworking volunteers.\t
column20: Esperance District Football Association, Community sports, Mental health

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Aligned with our corporate giving strategy, MADALAH believes education is the key to generational change and opportunity and is committed to Making a Difference in the lives of indigenous students from regional communities by offering secondary and tertiary education scholarships to some of Western Australia's leading boarding schools and universities. In 2023, MADALAH is supporting its largest cohort, awarding 105 secondary and 61 tertiary scholarships. \t
column20: MADALAH, Indigenous education, Scholarships

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Our partnership with Ronald McDonald House Charities WA (RMHC WA) is central to how we, as a business, Make a Difference, and year-on-year, the Up All Night event is not only a success for RMHC but has also become an important employee event in IGO's calendar. In November 2022, 30 IGO walkers and 13 IGO volunteers participated in the event, our largest team of IGO people since we began supporting Up All Night, to raise money for RMHC and walk in memory of Peter Bradford, an organisation he was passionate about supporting.\t
column20: Ronald McDonald House Charities WA, Up All Night event, Charity walk

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: IGO is a long-term supporter of the Royal Flying Doctors Service (RFDS), and this year, we are proud to be one of the matched giving partners for Flying Doctor Day again. The RFDS is critical to the continuity of our mining and exploration operations in emergencies and as a primary healthcare provider for many remote and regional communities. \t
column20: Royal Flying Doctors Service, Remote healthcare, Emergency services

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: IGO is a cornerstone partner of Teach Learn Grow (TLG) and has supported the organisation for nine years. In FY24, IGO will continue its support, and we have entered into a three-year agreement with a funding commitment of $180,000 over this period.\t
column20: Teach Learn Grow, Education support, Long-term partnership

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: 70th Annual Esperance and Districts Agricultural Show
column13: In October 2022, IGO was the primary sponsor of the 70th Annual Esperance and Districts Agricultural Show for the fourth year. The show is the most significant event in Esperance annually, attracting over 12,000 visitors over the two days. The show provides broad exposure for community engagement, bringing people together from Esperance and beyond to celebrate local businesses and the agricultural industry.\t
column20: Esperance and Districts Agricultural Show, Community event, Sponsorship

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: IGO is pleased to have a long-standing partnership with the Cannery Arts Centre in Esperance, including the KickArts program, which offers art-based workshops for local children during the school holidays. All children should be able to engage in arts-based learning to foster their imagination, innovation and creativity.\t
column20: Arts, culture, children\t

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: At the Nova and Forrestania Operations, we consider climate impacts and variability in our mining design and operation management practices. We are currently reviewing and streamlining our business continuity and emergency management planning across all our operations to ensure the best practice approach is consistently applied. Longer-term climate impacts are more relevant for these operations in our closure and rehabilitation planning, and we are currently working on integrating these into our closure activities.\t
column20: Climate impacts, Mining operations, Business continuity

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column7: At the end of FY23, IGO held 637 tenements, including 355 granted exploration licences, 115 exploration license applications, 82 granted mining leases and two mining lease applications. IGO's seven exploration groups engage with 38 Traditional Owner groups through Heritage Protection Agreements (HPAs) that manage our on-ground activity and relationships. IGO is also concluding a comprehensive mine project agreement at Cosmos with the Tjiwarl Traditional Owners via the Tjiwarl Aboriginal Corporation (TAC).\t

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: IGO's seven exploration groups engage with 38 Traditional Owner groups through Heritage Protection Agreements (HPAs) that manage our on-ground activity and relationships. IGO is also concluding a comprehensive mine project agreement at Cosmos with the Tjiwarl Traditional Owners via the Tjiwarl Aboriginal Corporation (TAC).\t
column20: Traditional Owners, Heritage Protection Agreements, Relationship

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: IGO actively pursues direct and respectful relationships through agreement-making and always strives to be a valued partner where we have an existing operation or exploration presence. IGO greatly values and appreciates the trust Traditional Owners place in IGO, and we will respect and do the right thing when operating in the country.\t
column20: Engagement, Cultural awareness training, Cross-Cultural Training

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: IGO's commitment to active and meaningful engagement is reflected in the expansion of our cultural awareness training opportunities to employees and long-term contractors to allow them to understand better the cultural heritage, history, and values of Traditional Owners in whose Country IGO operates. During FY23, five two-day Cross-Cultural Training (CCT) courses were undertaken with 57 IGO employees and contractors in attendance in the country near our Nova Operation.\t
column20: Production impacts, Health and safety, Supply chain disruptions

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column8: 2023 Ngadju and IGO Heritage Protection Agreement
column13: The new agreement aims to strengthen IGO's relationship with the Ngadju people by establishing an efficient land access process that complies with the Aboriginal cultural heritage regime and IGO's broad-scale non-ground disturbing exploration. IGO acknowledges and thanks NNTAC and the Ngadju people for bringing the NRHPA together for a much sounder long-term heritage arrangement between the parties. The agreement enables IGO to prioritise extensive exploration activity in the south area of the Albany Fraser Orogen project to extend the life of IGO's Nova Operation, which will provide future benefits to both IGO and the Ngadju people.\t
column20: Heavy rainfall, Storm events, Droughts

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: IGO's supplier due diligence and evaluation processes define the minimum sustainability requirements regarding each specific supplier engagement, acting as a methodology to ensure we prioritise ethical decision-making when selecting and managing the suppliers we work with and upholding fundamental human rights through our supply chain. We focus on sourcing individuals and organisations with shared values and consider macro-economic factors in our risk assessments that may impact goods and services.\t
column20: Product end-use transparency, code of conduct, statement\t

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: We have again sought greater transparency of our product end use by engaging our customers to understand the final application of our products. Based on public statements and advice from IGO's key nickel customers, we know most of our products are processed for use in downstream battery products. It aligns with our Company's strategy to supply products critical to clean energy and battery storage.\t
column20: Product end use, Customer engagement, Battery products

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: Our approach to responsible sourcing aligns with our purpose and strategy Ã¢ÂÂ ensuring the quality products we supply are made safely, ethically, sustainably and reliably. It extends further than our immediate operations and activities. The changing sentiment of conscious consumers choosing responsible brands and sustainably produced products drives companies to consider their supply value chain by ensuring responsible production and transparent oversight of their end-use.\t
column20: Transparency, Clean energy, Supply value chain
